title: 108_hr3458
content: The Act may be cited as the "Diabetic Retinopathy Prevention Act of 2003". The Congress finds that type 2 diabetes affects millions of Americans, leading to diabetic retinopathy which is the most common complication causing blindness. Early detection and treatment can reduce vision loss by 90 percent. The potential for reaching diabetic patients in rural or underserved areas without access to regular eye exams by specialists. Medicare coverage is expanded to include remote assessment of diabetic retinopathy, allowing for access to eye exams for diabetic patients in rural or underserved areas. The term 'remote assessment of diabetic retinopathy' refers to a diagnostic examination of the retina for early detection of diabetic retinopathy, provided annually to individuals with diabetes. The examination must meet technical standards set by the Secretary and be conducted via a telecommunications system by qualified healthcare professionals. Payment is allowed regardless of the provider's location. The amendments allow for remote assessments of diabetic retinopathy using store-and-forward technologies, with interim payment until final regulations are published. Additionally, a study on reimbursement for these assessments is required within a year. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on costs incurred by healthcare providers for remote assessment of diabetic retinopathy services, including per-patient and start-up/administrative costs. A report with recommendations on Medicare reimbursements and the need for repeating the study will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. The amendments will apply to assessments performed 30 days after the enactment of the Act. Medicaid will cover remote assessment of diabetic retinopathy. Medicaid will cover remote assessment of diabetic retinopathy, with amendments to the Social Security Act specifying the effective date and state compliance requirements. In a State with a 2-year legislative session, each year is considered a separate regular session of the State legislature. SEC. 5. MOBILE DIABETIC RETINOPATHY SCREENING PILOT PROGRAM. Amends Title III of the Public Health Service Act to establish a pilot program for mobile diabetic retinopathy screening. The Secretary will establish a grant program called the "Mobile Diabetic Retinopathy Screening Pilot Program" to provide grants to 5 eligible entities for setting up mobile diabetic retinopathy screening programs. Grants cannot exceed $1,000,000 per year, and entities must agree to use the funds for designing, demonstrating, and implementing the screening program. The Secretary will solicit applications for grants within 90 days of funds becoming available. The Secretary will prioritize applicants with experience in evaluating diabetic retinopathy using telecommunications equipment and serving rural, impoverished, minority, and remote populations. Grants cannot be awarded without notifying Congress at least 3 days prior. The Secretary must evaluate the program within 3 years of the first grant being awarded. The Secretary will convene an advisory committee to evaluate the Mobile Diabetic Retinopathy Screening Pilot Program's effectiveness in early detection and prevention of diabetic retinopathy. The committee will also assess if the program can be a model for similar screening programs for other chronic conditions. A report must be submitted within 42 months of the first grant being awarded. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress with the advisory committee's evaluation results. Definitions include terms like advisory committee, eligible entity, and mobile diabetic retinopathy screening program. The Mobile Diabetic Retinopathy Screening Pilot Program, established under the Social Security Act, focuses on serving patients in rural, underserved, and remote areas. The Program is mobile and has an authorization of appropriations of $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2005 to 2009.
